messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] spell check software
messages.msgSnippet: -=-Ours is called: Franklin Spelling Ace.-=- Holly says hers was called Homework Whiz. Here s a Brit version:
messages.messageBody:
-=-Ours is called: Franklin Spelling Ace.-=-

Holly says hers was called Homework Whiz.

Here's a Brit version:
http://www.comparestoreprices.co.uk/educational-toys/unbranded-homework-whiz-word-bank.asp


If that cuts off,
http://www.brightminds.co.uk/Homework-Whiz--Word-bank-A3120.htm

She used it as a toy, and it was a toy she learned a lot with.

Sandra

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] spell check software
messages.msgSnippet: McAfee SiteAdvisor Warning This e-mail message contains potentially unsafe links to these sites: download32.com   Alex Polikowsky http://polykow.blogspot.com/
messages.messageBody:
McAfee SiteAdvisor Warning
This e-mail message contains potentially unsafe links to these sites:
download32.com

 
Alex Polikowsky
http://polykow.blogspot.com/

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/unschoolingmn/
 




________________________________
From: Sandra Dodd <Sandra@...>
To: AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, March 28, 2009 10:38:01 AM
Subject: [AlwaysLearning] spell check software


I happened to come across this (and someone did ask about spell
checking):
http://www.download 32.com/spell- check-anywhere- i26878.html

It's a shareware thing for $29.
I respond to the list by e-mail, and I have a spelling option for that.

I don't know if that spell checker will work when someone typing on a
webpage.

When Holly was younger and wanted to spell more words, we got her a
little handheld spelling dictionary from Radio Shack that would guess
your word from a bad spelling, and play spelling games, and define
words and show how to write them in cursive, with an animation
program. She enjoyed that and I haven't mentioned it for a while.

Sandra




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
